intro: Gaylussacia incana, commonly known as the gray alder or northern highbush blueberry, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes many acid-loving plants. The plant is characterized by its slender, grayish branches and oval, dark green leaves that turn red in the fall. It produces small, bell-shaped flowers in the spring, which are followed by edible, blue-black berries. This species is often found in moist, acidic soils in woodlands and wetlands.
